data.title: Nostalgic Department store restaurant
data.text: This is a classic department store restaurant inside Macy's downtown (the original Kaufmann's store).  I love going here for traditional department store fare, although I think it was better when Kaufmann's was in control. It is still a good place to get a reasonable lunch and remember the wonderful days of downtown department stores.

data.title: Old School Department Store Diner
data.text: Tic Toc is located inside Macy's downtown Pittsburgh. It's just what you would expect from a mall/department store diner. Older crowd, older atmosphere. Food is decent.

data.title: Poor service
data.text: I work in Pittsburgh.  I usually eat at the counter.  When Mark is behind the counter the service is great.  I have gone a few times and he was not there and have sat there and no one bothers to wait on me.  I usually get up and leave after about 10 minutes.  There are other places to eat in Pittsburgh.  Macy's must not need the money.

data.title: Tic-Toc Restaurant
data.text: This restaurant is located in the old Kaufmann's building on Fifth Avenue in downtown Pittsburgh.  Haven't been there in a long time and was not impressed with the menu nor the food.  There hours are only from 11:00-3:00 everyday.  Service was good, but not impressed with the food at all.

data.title: Old Fashioned Department Store Luncheonette
data.text: Step back in time when eating here.  The food is good (try the pretzel chicken sandwich), the prices are remarkably low, the desserts are huge and sinful, the service is as expected.

data.title: Bit of nostalgia
data.text: The food is okay but the place is a little bit run down.  Older and also a little slow. I've been here many times and continue to wonder why I return as it is all average.

data.title: A Pittsburgh tradition
data.text: I used to eat here when I was in college, so stopped for lunch. Food was good, waitress was very attentive. It's not the same atmosphere as the old Tic Toc, but I enjoyed it just the same. I even treated myself to dessert, couldn't resist the fresh-baked apple strudel ala mode! And I caught up on my emails with free wifi.

data.title: Timeless classic
data.text: This timeless classic is located on the 1st floor of Macy's downtown.  Price very reasonable. Service was excellent. One of Pittsburgh's best kept secrets.

data.title: Quick, Functional Fare
data.text:
The Tic Toc is a venerable institution located in the former Kaufmann’s Department Store, itself a local favorite that with the passage of time and a changing urban economy has transmogrified into a Macy’s. During my recent lunch I considered a number of cafeteria type items such as meatloaf, chicken pot pie, the tic-toc burger and the “tic toc tea plate.” I settled on the open-faced smoked turkey platter, which turned out to be exactly what was expected: a thin slice of white turkey on a plain slice of white bread, piled atop mashed potatoes and topped with plenty of salty gravy. The quality reminded me of public cafeterias of the 1950s: Warm, filling, and undisturbed by the temptations of culinary nuance.

My waitress told me that the current incarnation of the Tic Toc, dating from 1958, was moved from its original higher level location to the department store’s ground floor. The restaurant sports a spacious seating area for around 150 people and a sparse but quirky décor that includes a selection of antique clocks along the back wall. I was especially impressed by a presentation of over two dozen historic black and white photos of Kaufmann’s from what looked to be the 1930s, and some even older prints going back to the early 20th century, including a shot of a charming merchant wagon. 

The Tic Toc, in short, is a virtual time machine into its host city’s vigorous past. While I have given the establishment only two stars for its uninspired food, the place is worth a visit to be transported to Pittsburgh’s heyday when Big Steel was king, America was a manufacturing titan and foreign competition was a small cloud on the horizon.

data.title: ...for the ladies.  Think tea sandwiches and cheesecake
data.text: ...for the ladies.  Think tea sandwiches and cheesecake

data.title: A Little Bit of History
data.text: I've eaten here many times over the past few years when passing through Pittsburgh.  It is nothing too fancy, but the food is good and very reasonably priced.  The Tic Toc is known for its Tic Toc Burger, but many other items are on the menu as well.  I like the fish sandwich and all of the burgers.  The onion rings are homemade and sure do taste it.  Breakfast is also served here, but I haven't had the opportunity to try it out.   If you go and are looking for desert, I would encourage anyone to get the Patio 5 cake.  It's delicious.  In fact, all of the desert is fantastic including the pies.  The wait staff is very attentive and friendly.  I enjoy going in for a bite to eat when in town because of the history of the building (the old Kaufmann's, now Macy's) and restaurant.  I'm sure this establishment was quite a place in the sixties as it really reminds me of a step back in time.  There's still a lunch counter and probably the same one from decades ago.  There are many different clocks on the back wall - a symbol of the restaurant's name.  Many department stores no longer have restaurants inside anymore, but this one sure does and it's great!   By the way, don't forget to stop by the pastry and desert shop on the arcade level of the store.
